I. 

THE PROPOSAL  

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
loan,  and  (ii)  the  proposed  administration  of  a  loan  to  be  provided  by  the  OPEC  Fund  for 
International  Development  (OFID),  both  to  Nepal  for  the  Secondary  Towns  Integrated  Urban 
Environmental Improvement Project. 
 
The  project1 will  improve  the  quality  of  life  in  key  regional  centers  in  Nepal  and  help 
2. 
achieve higher and more socially inclusive economic growth in those centers through effective, 
efficient,  and  reliable  delivery  of  improved  and  affordable  municipal  services  by  accountable 
project  municipalities.  Integrated  urban  environmental  improvements,  including  sewerage  and 
drainage  systems,  solid  waste  management  facilities,  and  urban  roads  and  lanes,  will  be 
implemented  in  Biratnagar,  Birgunj,  and  Butwal  municipalities.2 A  water  supply  development 
subproject will also be carried out in three other municipalities–Banepa, Dhulikhel, and Panauti– 
in the Kavre valley.3 At the same time, the project will make communities more aware of health 
and  hygiene  and  the  need  to  reduce,  reuse,  and  recycle  (the  3Rs),  and  it  will  invest  in 
small-scale community facilities. It will also strengthen the capacity of the municipalities and the 
central government to manage and run the project. The environment for development work has 
greatly improved since 2006, when the decade-long conflict ended. The experience of the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  has  shown  that  active  community  participation  can  insulate 
development  work  from  a  country’s  wider  challenges  and  thus  bring  about  effective  service 
delivery. The scope of the project is well aligned with the priorities of the municipalities; strong 
support  from  stakeholders,  including  local  representatives  of  all  major  political  parties  was 
confirmed  during  project  preparation.  The  project  design  and  implementation  arrangements 
have  fully  taken  into  account  the  current  political  context  in  Nepal,  with  the  implementation 
expected to proceed amid the ongoing peace process. 4 The project is also closely aligned with 
the priorities and areas of focus under ADB’s Nepal country partnership strategy,5 and supports 
the country's peace and development through improved access to basic services.  

A. 

Rationale 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

The  National  Urban  Policy  adopted  by  the  government  in  2007  gives  priority  to              

3. 
(i)  achieving  a  balanced  national  urban  structure6 by  directing  infrastructure  development  and 
investment; (ii) improving the quality of urban life by building a clean, safe, and well-developed 
urban  environment;  and  (iii)  setting  up  effective  urban  management  by  empowering  capable 
local  institutions.  The  3-year  interim  plan  (FY2008–FY2010)  under  the  policy  looks  forward  to 
government  investments  in  urban  infrastructure  and  other  services,  and  to  local  institutions 
                                                 
1   The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  Nepal  in  2008  for 

Preparing the Secondary Towns Integrated Urban Environmental Improvement Project. 

2   The National Urban Policy (2007) refers to Biratnagar, Birgunj, and Butwal as possible regional economic centers 

in the Eastern, Central, and Western regions, respectively.  

3   This subproject was to have been implemented under the ongoing Urban and Environmental Improvement Project 
(ADB.  2002.  Report  and  Recommendation  of  the  President  to  the  Board  of  Directors:  Proposed  Loan  to  the 
Kingdom of Nepal for the Urban and Environmental Improvement Project. Manila [Loan 1966-NEP]). But only the 
project  preparatory  work  (detailed  design  and  environmental  impact  assessment)  will  be  completed  under  the 
ongoing  project.  The  government  has  requested  ADB  support  for  the  physical  investment  under  the  proposed 
project.   

4  On 28 May 2010, the Constituent Assembly extended its term for one year to draft the new constitution.  
5  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: Nepal, 2010–2012. Manila.  
6   A “balanced urban structure” is a state of evenly managed urban development in every development region. Every 

region should have at least one regional urban center with industrial and commercial activities.  

 2 

 

empowered and strengthened to build a clean, safe, and prosperous urban environment. While 
productivity  in  the  urban  areas  is  higher  and  poverty  substantially  lower,  infrastructure 
development  and  service  delivery  have  fallen  behind  in  those  areas.  Public  investments  have 
not  kept  pace  with  the  growth  of  the  urban  population,  swelled  (by  more  than  5%  yearly)  by 
internal conflicts and the dearth of economic and employment opportunities in the countryside. 
Urban  environmental  conditions,  already  deteriorating,  have  worsened:  inaccessible  and 
poor-quality  drinking  water  and  sanitation  facilities,  uncollected  or  improperly  dumped  waste, 
water pollution from untreated domestic and industrial wastewater, and waterlogging. Moreover, 
urban  services  outside  the  Kathmandu  valley  are  scarce. 7  As  a  result,  premature  death, 
disease,  and  associated  economic  burdens  disproportionately  affect  the  poor  and  the 
vulnerable.  The  World  Bank  estimates  annual  urban  health  costs  related  to  inadequate  water 
and sanitation at $12 million,8 and the World Health Organization ascribes 24% of the burden of 
disease in Nepal to environmental factors.9 Poor health saps economic growth by reducing labor 
productivity and holding back educational attainment. 
 
4. 
Further development in the Kathmandu valley has its physical limits. New urban centers 
will  inevitably  emerge.  But  the  urban  environment  in  the  urban  centers  urgently  needs 
improvement  to  make  up  the  lag  in  economic  development  in  towns  outside  the  valley  and 
promote  social  and  economic  development  in  the  regions  of  Nepal.  The  municipalities  of 
Biratnagar,  Birgunj,  and  Butwal  were  selected  for  the  project  from  13  candidate  towns  on  the 
basis  of  (i)  economic  growth  potential,  (ii)  demand  for  urban  services,  and  (iii)  urban 
management  capacity.10 Each  town  is  the  main  urban  center  of  an  industrial  corridor  and  of 
importance in external trade.11 
  
The project is in line with ADB’s Nepal country partnership strategy, which rests on four 
5. 
pillars: broad-based and inclusive economic growth, inclusive social development, governance 
and  capacity  building,  and  climate  change  adaptation  and  environmental  sustainability. 
Reflecting lessons from similar projects,12 the project (i) focuses on a small number of physically 
improvement,  and  solid  waste 
integrated  components  (drainage,  sewerage  and  road 
management in the same area) to simplify administration and coordination; (ii) is confined to a 
few larger municipalities with relatively higher technical and financial capacity to implement the 
project  and  create  visible  impact;  (iii)  fully  involves  stakeholders  in  project  identification  and 
design  from  an  early  stage;  and  (iv)  provides  capacity  development  support13 before  project 
implementation.   

                                                 
7   According to the most recent living standard survey in Nepal, only 30.4% of households in urban areas outside the 
valley  have  access  to  sewerage  systems  (compared  with  98.1%  in  the  valley)  and  only  24.1%  have  access  to 
garbage  collection  and  disposal  systems  (compared  with  83.0%).  Government  of  Nepal.  2004.  Nepal  Living 
Standard Survey 2003/04. Kathmandu. 

8   World Bank. 2007. Nepal Country Environmental Analysis. Washington, DC. 
9  World Health Organization. 2009. Country Profiles of Environmental Burden of Disease. Geneva. 
10 The evaluation criteria were arrived at and the analyses made under  the project preparatory TA (footnote 1). The 
government, represented by the Department of Urban Development and Building Construction, was fully engaged 
in the whole process and endorsed the conclusions. In 2008, Biratnagar had an estimated population of 199,000, 
Birgunj 157,000, and Butwal 108,000.  

11 The  project  will  have  a  regional  (cross-border)  aspect.  Urban  environmental  improvements  in  Biratnagar  and 
Birgunj  will  have  positive  spillover  effects  in  India,  as  (i) many  daily  visitors  from  India  engage  in  trade,  and 
(ii) rivers going through the two municipalities immediately flow into India. (Customs points at Birgunj handled about 
80% of overseas trade in 2008, and Biratnagar, about 16%.) 

12  Including the ongoing Urban and Environmental Improvement Project (footnote 3).  
13  Capacity development TA was approved in September 2009 to strengthen the capacity of Biratnagar, Birgunj, and 
Butwal  municipalities  in  (i) financial  management  including  revenue  enhancement,  (ii) technical  aspects  of  urban 
service  delivery,  and  (iii) development  of  geographic  information  system–based  urban  mapping.  ADB.  2009. 
Technical Assistance to Nepal for Institutional Strengthening of Municipalities. Manila.  

 B. 

Impact and Outcome 

6. 
The  impact  will  be  improved  quality  of  life  and  higher  and  more  socially  inclusive 
economic growth in key regional centers in Nepal. The expected outcome will be improved and 
affordable  municipal  services  delivered  effectively,  efficiently,  and  reliably  by  accountable 
project municipalities.  

C. 

Output 

7. 
The  project  will  have  two  components.  In  component  1  priority  subprojects  will  be 
implemented  and  reliable,  affordable,  and  effective  municipal  infrastructure  developed  in  each 
municipality. The selection of subprojects follows the priorities set by the municipalities in their 
municipal  periodic  plans.14 During  detailed  design,  the  municipalities  will  assess  the  possibility 
of private sector participation in the operation and maintenance (O&M) of the infrastructure from 
the viewpoint of effective and efficient system operation, determine the appropriate form of such 
participation,  and  reflect  the  findings  in  the  institutional  arrangement.  The  capacity  of  the 
municipalities and the central government to manage and run the project will be strengthened in 
component 2.  

1. 

Component 1: Developing Reliable, Affordable, and Effective Municipal 
Infrastructure  

Drainage  and  sewerage.  Biratnagar  and  Birgunj,  on  the  flatland  of  the  Terai,15 are 
8. 
chronically  waterlogged  because  of  inadequate,  poorly  built,  and  poorly  maintained  drainage 
and  obstructions  from  solid  waste  dumping.  Stormwater  drainage  systems  are  being  used  as 
open  sewers,  causing  bad  odors  and  health  risks,  and  polluting  the  watercourses.  These 
systems  will  be  improved  together  with  wastewater  management  systems,  and  wastewater 
treatment plants16 will be built in both municipalities. Urban roads and lanes will be restored or 
upgraded in places where work is done on drainage and sewerage pipe networks.  
 
9. 
Solid  waste  management. Without a sanitary landfill, Birgunj and Butwal dump waste 
haphazardly along riverbanks and into open spaces, with little recycling, causing pollution and 
public health hazards. The project will take an integrated approach to solid waste management, 
reviewing  and  improving  the  entire  system  from  segregation  and  collection,  through  the  3Rs 
(including the composting of organic waste), to transportation and final disposal at the sanitary 
landfill. The necessary equipment and vehicles will thus be procured and a sanitary landfill site17 
built  in  each  municipality.  A  preliminary  assessment  of  the  potential  for  using  the  Clean 
Development  Mechanism  for  composting  has  been  made;  further  studies  will  be  done  during 
detailed design.  
 
10.  Water  supply.  Water  supply  subprojects  will  be  implemented  in  the  municipalities  of 
Banepa,  Dhulikhel,  and  Panauti  in  the  Kavre  valley18 and  in  Butwal,  where  there  is  a  severe 
shortage.  The  Kavre  valley  subproject  will  take  a  regional  approach.  A  single  project

Birgunj in 2009, and is being prepared in Butwal.  
15  The Terai is the southern plain area bordering India. 
16  Waste stabilization ponds will be established as the least-cost option. In Biratnagar, a reed-bed treatment plant will 

also be built.  

17  The  site  will  be  developed  as  an  integrated  resource  recovery  center  to  optimize  resource  recovery,  although 

facilities for resource recovery are not part of the project.  

18  The three municipalities in the Kavre valley had a total population of about 59,000 in 2009.  

3 

 

 4 

 

Other 

implementation unit (PIU) will be formed to implement the project, and the Kavre Water Supply 
Management Board19 will be created to take charge of O&M.  
 
11. 
infrastructure.  Auto-related  enterprises  (workshops;  motor  parts  makers, 
painters, welders, repairers) have clustered in Butwal, at the strategic juncture of the East–West 
Highway  and  the  Siddhartha  Highway  (north–south  corridor).  The  project  will  improve  basic 
infrastructure  such  as  roads,  wastewater  management,  and  water  supply  in  this  auto  industry 
zone (auto village) through public–private partnership.  
 
12. 
Community  development  programs.  This  subcomponent  will  consist  mainly  of 
(i) health  and  hygiene  education  in  communities  and  schools, 20 particularly  for  women  and 
vulnerable  groups  including  the  poor;  (ii)  household  and  community  3R  activities,  particularly 
organic  waste  composting;  (iii)  skills  training,  mainly  for  the  poor;  and  (iv)  investment  in 
small-scale facilities that are community priorities, such as public, school, and community toilets 
and communal water taps, to achieve social inclusiveness and improve sanitation in Biratnagar, 
Birgunj, and Butwal municipalities.21 A portion of this subcomponent could be devoted to making 
it  easier  for  the  poor  to  connect  to  sanitation  (mainly  for  on-site  sanitation)  and  water  supply 
services with the help of performance-based grants such as output-based aid.22 As the project 
will  bring  tangible  benefits  to  women  through  better  access  to  municipal  services  and  more 
meaningful participation, it is classified as effective gender mainstreaming (para. 26).  
 
13. 
Consulting  services  for  design,  construction  supervision,  and  support  for  the  initial 
operation of facilities for the above subcomponents (except community development programs) 
will also be part of this component. The services will include (i) the development of the technical 
capacity of municipal staff to carry out O&M of the facilities built under the project; (ii) support in 
setting  and  collecting  adequate  tariffs,  taxes,  and  other  charges  to  ensure  that  enough  is 
allocated  in  the  budget  for  O&M,  repayment  to  the  Town  Development  Fund  (TDF), 
replacement,  and  future  expansion;  and  (iii)  assessment  of  the  possibility  of  private  sector 
participation in service delivery and its appropriate form. Local nongovernment organizations will 
be hired to assist in the community development programs.  

 

2. 

Component 2: Strengthening the Capacity of Municipalities and the Central 
Government for Project Management and Operation  

14. 
This  component  will  support  the  smooth  and  effective  implementation  and  operation  of 
the project. Project municipalities will be provided with capacity development programs sufficient 
for  the  creation  or  strengthening  of  institutions  such  as  the  units  responsible  for  O&M.23 To 
establish the Kavre Water Supply Management Board and make it operational, support will be 
provided in (i) asset valuation and transfer, (ii) institutional development including the drafting of 
regulations and a business plan, and (iii) system integration.

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

20. 
The  executing  agency  will  be  the  Ministry  of  Physical  Planning  and  Works,  working 
through its Department of Urban Development and Building Construction. It will set up a project 
coordination office (PCO) to be headed by the project director. Biratnagar, Birgunj, and Butwal 
municipalities, each with a PIU headed by a project manager, will be the implementing agencies 
for  the  subprojects.  Another  PIU,  comprising  representatives  from  Banepa,  Dhulikhel,  and 
Panauti municipalities, will be created for the Kavre valley water supply subproject.

A. 

Economic and Financial 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

22. 
The public investment to be made under the project, coupled with various programs to 
increase community awareness of sanitation and numerous community sanitation schemes, will 
have  a  significant  impact  on  the  environment  and  public  health  improvement.  An  economic 
analysis  of  the  combined  public  investment  in  each  municipality  measured  the  consequent 
reduction in the occurrence of waterborne diseases and the private health-care cost and found 
these  to  be  economically  viable.  The  economic  internal  rates  of  return  range  from  13.9%  to 
                                                 
27  Development Coordination (Appendix 2). 

7 

 

 8 

 

23.2%, higher than the economic opportunity cost of capital. Moreover, underestimation of the 
economic returns is likely because only a portion of the benefits can be captured in numerical 
values. 
 
The  financial  management  assessment  brought  out  common  financial  management 
23. 
practices among the implementing agencies. A sound financial management system is in place, 
although  the  implementing  agencies  still  use  a  cash-based  accounting  system.  The  financial 
management  specialist  will  assist  the  implementing  agencies  in  maintaining  the  project 
accounts according to double-entry accrual accounting. An assessment of the financial position 
of the municipalities has found these public investments financially sustainable. 

B. 

Governance 

24. 
A  governance  risk  assessment  of  public  financial  management,  procurement,  and 
corruption in the urban development sector was made when the country partnership strategy for 
Nepal  was  prepared  in  2009.  The  financial  management  risks  of  the  municipalities  are  being 
addressed  through  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (footnote  13).  ADB  and  other 
development partners are supporting the capacity building of relevant government agencies to 
lessen public procurement and corruption risks. Transparency, in procurement and financing as 
well  as  other  matters,  will  be  maximized  under  the  project  to  reduce  central  and  local 
government risks. 
  
25. 
ADB’s  Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  has  been  explained  to  and 
discussed with the government. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM. 

C. 

Poverty and Social 

26. 
The  Project  is  classified  as  effective  gender  mainstreaming.  The  improvements  to  be 
made  in  drainage  and  sewerage  infrastructure  and  solid  waste  management  systems  will 
produce significant public health benefits for the community in general, including the poor. While 
drainage and sewerage system improvement will not cover the entire municipal areas, the poor 
living  in  the  peripheral  areas  will  also  benefit  from  the  project,  as  community  development 
programs  will  be  directed  at  women  and  vulnerable  groups  including  the  poor.  Small-scale 
facilities,  such  as  communal  water  taps  and  communal  toilets  that  will  give  the  poor  better 
access to water supply and sanitation, will be supported. The promotion of 3R programs is also 
expected to benefit the poor and women. These programs will be participatory, with women and 
vulnerable groups appropriately represented. A gender equality and social inclusion action plan 
will  be  implemented  to  ensure  inclusiveness  in  the  project  and  address  the  different  needs  of 
women and vulnerable groups. 

D. 

Safeguards 

Environmental  safeguards.  The  project  is  category  B  in  accordance  with  the  ADB 
27. 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).  The  executing  agency  and  implementing  agencies 
prepared  initial  environmental  examinations,  including  environmental  management  plans 
(EMPs), for the subprojects during the feasibility study. Specific locations were identified for all 
major infrastructure and facilities; for some small-scale facilities, such as water supply in Butwal 
and  community  and  school  toilets,  the  locations  will  be  fixed  after  Board  approval.  An 
environmental assessment and review framework was therefore also prepared. The framework 
sets  out  the  requirements  for  project  screening  and  classification,  subproject  selection, 

 information disclosure to and consultation with the affected people, environmental assessment, 
EMP development and implementation, and monitoring and reporting. The initial environmental 
examinations found the planned subprojects to have only small and localized adverse impact on 
the environment, which can be mitigated with the mitigation measures proposed in the EMPs. 
On  the  other  hand,  the  improvements  in  drainage  and  sewerage  systems  and  in  solid  waste 
management  will  have  significant  positive  impact  on  community  hygiene  and  sanitation.  The 
EMPs will be implemented by the PIUs and the implementation will be monitored by the PCO. 
Design and supervision consultants will assist the PIUs in implementing the EMPs.  
 
28. 
Social safeguards. The project is category B for involuntary resettlement and category 
B  for  indigenous  peoples  in  accordance  with  the  ADB  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  Several 
subprojects 
involuntary 
resettlement impact is not considered significant.28 Draft resettlement plans have been prepared 
for  these  subprojects  in  compliance  with  the  government’s  and  ADB’s  policy  requirements.  A 
resettlement framework has also been prepared. The PCO will see to it that the PIUs update the 
resettlement plan, if needed, during detailed design and implement the final resettlement plan. 
Considering the nature and scale of these subprojects, the impact on indigenous peoples will be 
limited to a few involuntary resettlement and land acquisition cases. The draft resettlement plan 
includes  an  indigenous  peoples  plan,  and  the  resettlement  framework  includes  an  indigenous 
peoples planning framework, with special assistance measures for indigenous people and other 
vulnerable  groups.  As  sanitation  services  improve,  so  will  the  health  benefits  for  indigenous 
people.  In  addition,  the  gender  equality  and  social  inclusion  plan  contains  specific  actions 
favorable to indigenous people.
